Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Identifying the Molecular Origins of Enzyme Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Experimental Physical Chemistry Program of the Chemistry Division and the Molecular Biochemistry Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biology of the Biology Directorate, Prof. Christopher Cheatum of the University of Iowa, and his graduate student colleagues will work to study the dynamics of enzyme-inhibitor interactions on the femtosecond to picosecond time scale. Prof. Cheatum and his group will use a multidisciplinary approach to do this using infrared photon echo and two-dimensional infrared spectroscopies on a variety of isozymes and their site-selected mutants. The ultimate goal of these types of studies is to develop a better model of enzyme catalysis, enabling more rational approaches to drug design and industrial biocatalysis.

Besides the broader scientific impact of these studies, Prof. Cheatum will invite high school teachers to spend a paid summer in his laboratory, as a member of his research team. The hope is that these teachers will return to their classrooms with a better understanding about the nature of science and scientific inquiry and that they will impart some of this to their students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The motions of enzymes are believed to play a role in drug binding and understanding these motions is a major obstacle in designing new drugs that target specific enzymes. Our research has used a powerful new technique based on state-of-the-art laser measurements to probe the motions of enzymes at the timescale of a thousandth of a billionth of a second, which is believed to be the most important timescale for understanding how the enzyme motions affect the chemistry that occurs within the enzyme. The results of our experiments have provided some of the first insights into enzyme motions at this timescale and have established that our approach is suitable for such studies. In addition, we have developed new ways of labeling enzymes to make them accessible to such methods so that we can expand the range of enzymes that can be studied using our methods. These results lay the foundation for further studies of important enzyme systems that have been the focus of many investigations about the role of enzyme motions in the chemistry. Many of these systems are important targets for pharamceutical applications and the work we have done makes those important targets accessible for study by the new methods we have helped to establish.
